openai_summarised_points: • Nutmeg is one of Grenada's key exports, highlighting its importance in the country's trade economy.
• The economy of Grenada is largely based on tourism, characterized as small and open, indicating a significant reliance on external markets and services.

• Between the 1980s and the 2000s, Grenada experienced a structural shift in its economic sectors, moving from agriculture dominance to a service-oriented economy, with tourism becoming the leading sector for foreign currency earnings.
• The principal export crops of Grenada include spices such as nutmeg and mace, with the country being the world's second-largest producer of nutmeg, following Indonesia.
• Additional export crops encompass cocoa, citrus fruits, bananas, cloves, and cinnamon, diversifying Grenada's agricultural export base.

• Manufacturing industries in Grenada are predominantly small-scale operations, including the production of beverages, other foodstuffs, textiles, and the assembly of electronic components for export.
• Economic growth in Grenada increased in the late 1990s after a period of slow growth and domestic fiscal adjustment during the early 1990s.
• Despite an expansionary fiscal policy during this period, the public debt remained moderate at approximately 50 percent of GDP, with deficits financed partly through privatization receipts.
• Since 2001, Grenada's economic growth has declined due to adverse shocks such as a slowdown in the global economy and natural disasters.
• In response to these shocks, fiscal policy became more expansionary, and privatization receipts declined, leading to a sharp increase in public debt to nearly 110 percent of GDP by 2003.
• The impact of Hurricane Ivan in September 2004 further worsened economic conditions; reconstruction efforts were initiated with significant aid from the international community.
• Post-hurricane, fiscal consolidation was hindered as government revenues fell, and policy priorities shifted towards relief efforts, delaying economic recovery.

• Although reconstruction proceeded rapidly, aided by international assistance, the sectors of tourism and agriculture remained weak, nearly offsetting the economic stimulus from reconstruction activities.
• Grenada continues to face challenges related to reconstruction and recovery, with public debt considered unsustainable and large financing gaps persisting.
• Reinvigorating economic growth remains a high priority for Grenada, requiring continued efforts to address vulnerabilities and promote sustainable development.
• The economy of Grenada is characterized as small, with tourism serving as its largest source of foreign exchange earnings.
• Grenada shares a common central bank with the Organisation of Eastern Caribbean States (OECS) and uses the East Caribbean dollar as its official currency.
• Following tourism, Grenada's economy depends heavily on agricultural exports, primarily various spices.
• The major agricultural exports of Grenada include nutmeg, wheat flour, and a variety of fruits, with data from 2017 indicating these constitute the majority of exports.
• Since gaining independence, Grenada has faced numerous economic challenges, notably a rising fiscal deficit and a substantial debt burden that hampers government operations.
• In 2004, Hurricane Ivan caused significant setbacks to Grenada's economy, damaging infrastructure and economic stability.
• The global financial crisis of 2008, known as the Great Recession, also adversely affected Grenada's economy, partly due to the United States being one of its largest trade partners.
• In 2017, Grenada was ranked nine positions above the bottom among 126 developing countries in terms of total debt, indicating a high debt level relative to other developing nations.
• During the late 1990s, Grenada experienced an average annual GDP growth rate of nearly six percent.
• Post-2001, economic growth significantly declined due to a downturn in the tourism industry following the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks, combined with damages from several hurricanes.
• In September 2004, Hurricane Ivan brought the Grenadian economy to a near standstill, damaging or destroying approximately 90 percent of the country's buildings, including key tourist facilities.
• In July 2005, Hurricane Emily struck Grenada while the country was still recovering from Hurricane Ivan’s impact.
• The hurricanes caused extensive damage to Grenada’s tree crops, destroying or severely damaging a large percentage of them, with recovery expected to take several years.
• The economic damage from Hurricane Ivan exceeded 200 percent of Grenada’s GDP, leading to a negative GDP growth of three percent in 2004, contrasting with a 5.8 percent positive growth in 2003.
• Despite signs of economic recovery after Hurricanes Ivan and Emily, overall conditions remained challenging, with GDP projected to grow by only one percent in 2005.
• After 2001, the fiscal situation deteriorated due to a continued expansionary fiscal policy characterized by increased spending on social sectors, wages, and goods and services.
• The fiscal deficit rose from 3.2 percent of GDP in 2000 to 8.5 percent in 2001.
• In 2002, the fiscal deficit widened further to 19.2 percent of GDP, primarily due to reduced output caused by Tropical Storm Lili.
• As the economy began to recover in 2003, the government initiated fiscal consolidation measures, reducing the deficit to 4.8 percent of GDP.
• In 2004, fiscal consolidation efforts were hindered by a policy shift towards post-hurricane relief, and government revenues declined due to hurricane impacts.
• Since 2001, adverse shocks such as a slowdown in the global economy and natural disasters contributed to declining economic growth.

• Fiscal policy became more expansionary as privatization receipts declined, leading to a sharp increase in public debt, which exceeded 100 percent of GDP since 2002 and approached 130 percent in 2004.
• Grenada is a member of the Eastern Caribbean Central Bank (ECCB), which manages monetary policy and issues a common currency for member countries.
• Inflation in Grenada has remained low and stable under the currency board arrangement, averaging around two percent over the past 15 years.
• Grenada's current account balance has consistently remained in large deficit, primarily due to its heavy reliance on imports of most consumer goods and domestic investment needs.
• Between 1997 and 2000, the country experienced an average current account deficit of approximately 44 percent of GDP.
• Since 2001, the current account deficit has increased to over 35 percent of GDP, driven by higher import demand coupled with reduced receipts from tourism and nutmeg exports.
• The deficits are financed through various inflows, including foreign direct investment (FDI), official grants and loans, and commercial borrowing by the private sector.
• Grenada's economy is highly vulnerable to external shocks because of its significant dependence on tourism, exports, and the importation of most goods consumed or invested domestically.
• The economy is also susceptible to adverse shocks such as natural disasters, which can further impact its financial stability.
• Following Hurricanes Ivan and Emily, Grenada's primary focus is on ongoing recovery efforts to restore infrastructure severely damaged by these natural disasters.

• The international community has provided substantial aid to Grenada, including financial assistance through the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) emergency assistance policy specifically designed for natural disasters.
• Additional aid has been received from the World Bank and the Caribbean Development Bank to support Grenada’s recovery and development initiatives.
• In terms of regional economic development, Grenada aims to deepen its integration into the Eastern Caribbean regional economy to bolster its competitiveness.
• Greater regional integration is expected to enhance Grenada’s capacity in production, marketing, and distribution, thereby increasing its economic scale.
• In 2013, Grenada launched a citizenship by investment program as part of its strategy to attract foreign investment and stimulate economic growth.
• Grenada joined the International Monetary Fund (IMF) on August 27, 1975.
• Since joining, Grenada has been subject to extensive review and oversight by the IMF.
• As a result of its engagement with the IMF, Grenada has become eligible to receive special drawing rights (SDRs).
• Special drawing rights (SDRs) are supplementary foreign exchange reserve assets established and maintained by the IMF.
• The allocation of SDRs to Grenada is based on its economic performance and policy adherence.
• Grenada's eligibility for additional SDRs depends on its economic and policy performance, with potential for increased SDR allocations.
• Over recent years, Grenada and the IMF have collaborated closely to promote economic growth and sustainability.
• The Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of Grenada, measured by purchasing power parity, was estimated at $1.401 billion in 2015.
• The real GDP growth rate in 2015 was 4.6%.
• The GDP per capita, based on purchasing power parity, was approximately $13,100 in 2015.
• The composition of GDP by sector in 2015 was: agriculture at 6.2%, industry at 14.3%, and services at 79.5%.
• As of 2008, approximately 38% of Grenada's population was living below the poverty line.
• Data on household income or consumption share for the lowest and highest 10% is not available (NA%).
• The inflation rate for consumer prices in 2015 was 1.3%.
• The labor force in 2013 comprised approximately 59,900 individuals.
• Occupational distribution of the labor force in 2008 was: services at 69%, industry at 20%, and agriculture at 11%.
• The unemployment rate in 2013 was notably high at 33.5%.
• The government’s budget in 2012 had revenues totaling $191.8 million and expenditures of $230.9 million.
• Key industries include food and beverages, textiles, light assembly operations, tourism, and construction.
• The industrial production growth rate in 2015 was -1%, indicating a slight contraction.
• Electricity production in 2012 was 193 GWh.
• Electricity generation by source in 2012 was predominantly fossil fuels at 98.2%, with hydro and nuclear contributing 0%, and other sources accounting for 1.4%.
• Electricity consumption in 2012 was 178 GWh.
• Grenada exported 0 kWh of electricity in 2013 and imported 0 kWh in the same year.
• Agricultural products include bananas, cocoa, nutmeg, mace, citrus, avocados, root crops, sugarcane, maize, and vegetables.
• The total value of exports in 2015 was $43.8 million.
• Major export commodities are nutmeg, bananas, cocoa, fruits and vegetables, clothing, and mace.
• Export partner countries in 2015 included Nigeria (44.7%), St. Lucia (10.8%), Antigua and Barbuda (7.3%), St. Kitts and Nevis (6.6%), Dominica (6.6%), and the United States (5.8%).
• Imports in 2015 amounted to $310.4 million, primarily consisting of food, manufactured goods, machinery, chemicals, and fuel.
• Main import partners were Trinidad and Tobago (49.6%) and the United States (16.4%) in 2015.
• External debt was approximately $679 million in 2013.
• In 1995, Grenada received $8.3 million in economic aid.
• The national currency is the East Caribbean dollar (EC$), with 1 EC$ equal to 100 cents.
• The fixed exchange rate since 1976 is 2.7000 EC$ per US dollar.
• The fiscal year in Grenada follows the calendar year.
